title: DO NOT MERGE - Stmgr Ability to specify the network interface to bind to
body:
Please consider this as an initial pull request for binding Stream manager to a specific network interface. I did this to test Stream manager on IPoIB interfaces.

The specific network interface can be specified as a configuration parameter in heron_internals.yaml file.  with the property heron.streammgr.network.options.bind.interface

In case of binding to a specific interface, we start a separate listening port on loopback connection to listen to local connections.

title: Statically link libunwind
body:
Currently stream manager links libunwind dynamically, which makes it harder to deploy heron in an Aurora cluster. This PR makes stream manager linking libunwind statically as other dependencies.

This is based on the previous work from @kramasamy @taishi8117 @zuyu (#923)

After this PR:

```
[heron-core]$ ldd bin/heron-stmgr
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffc91ed2000)
	libstdc++.so.6 => /lib64/libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007f6437e24000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib64/libm.so.6 (0x00007f6437b22000)
	libpthread.so.0 => /lib64/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f6437903000)
	librt.so.1 => /lib64/librt.so.1 (0x00007f64376fb000)
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib64/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f64374e4000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib64/libc.so.6 (0x00007f6437122000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x000055f267a0c000)

```

This resolves https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/505

title: Implementation of dry-run
body:
`submit` and `update` now supports `--dry-run`, which will output packing plan without actually submitting/updating topology. There are only supported formats now: raw and table. Raw render basically dumps out the packing plan, while table render will format packing plan and change (if there is any) in a table.

See https://github.com/twitter/heron/issues/1619 for more

title: Move Scheduler related spi util classes into schedulers package
body:
As #1604 mentioned, this PR is trying to move some `spi-classes` into schedulers package. 

There are five src and two test classes included totally:
```
c.t.h.spi.utils.Runtime
c.t.h.spi.utils.SchedulerConfig
c.t.h.spi.utils.Shutdown
c.t.h.spi.utils.LauncherUtils
c.t.h.spi.utils.SchedulerUtils

c.t.h.spi.utils.SchedulerUtils.LauncherUtilsTest
c.t.h.spi.utils.SchedulerUtils.SchedulerUtilsTest
```

The key changes are following:

* move classes into `c.t.h.schedulers.utils`
* modify `c.t.h.schedulers.BUILD` and modify `c.t.h.scheduler-core.BUILD`
* modify related class invoke info 

I've no idea about how to refactor `SchedulerConfig` class. So this PR only move it into schedulers package without any change. Let me know if there has anything I could do and any comment is welcomed.

cc @billonahill

title: using constant instead of utf8 string in heron package
body:
As #1598 mentioned, this PR is trying to use constant instead of `UTF-8` string on Java side in heron package. I've just modify the code in heron package, the contrib package is not included. If so, I can modify them as well. I'm not sure if I've found all the `UTF-8` strings in heron package. Please let me know if I have any omissions.

The key changes are following:

* remove `import java.nio.charset.Charset` and add `java.nio.charset.StandardCharsets`
* replace `Charset.forName("UTF-8")` to `StandardCharsets.UTF_8`

There are four classes included:

* heron/spi/utils/SchedulerUtils.java
* heron/scheduler/aurora/AuroraScheduler.java
* heron/spi/utils/ShellUtils.java
* heron/integration_test/common/HdfsHelper.java

title: Wait for a new pplan properly
body:
In test case StMgr.test_tmaster_restart_on_same_address, currently we wait for 3 seconds for a new pplan to come in and then check for the new pplan. This is broken if we don't receive the new pplan within 3 seconds. So, just wait for the change of the pplan.

This should resolve #1592.

repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Separate config params for SCP/SSH options and target host
body:
Currently, the `heron.uploader.scp.command.options` config value is incorrectly used to build and execute a SCP command, which causes the topology package upload to fail when using the ScpUploader. 

A correct scp invocation looks like this: `scp <options> <src> <user@host>:<dest>`
The current implementation of ScpController formats the command line like this: `scp <src> <heron.uploader.scp.command.options>:<dest>`

Because scp expects options to be set before specifying the source file, the upload fails if `heron.uploader.scp.command.options` contains both options and a user@host pair. Note that [the documentation](http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/operators/deployment/uploaders/scp/) gives an incorrect example.

This PR aims to fix this issue by separating the SCP options and user@host pair into two distinct configuration parameters which are then used by the ScpController to format a correct command line.

I'm still unsure whether or not the name `connection` for the user@host pair is appropriate...

title: Add a configurable memory cap for mempool
body:
Currently mempool is unbounded and memory in mempool grows and settles on steady state. This causes stream manager could use a lot of memory in production. We need a mechanism to add a cap there, the memory usage of stmgr is reduced down to 10% and meanwhile performance is almost not affected at all.

Note, I use a global limit for all instances of BaseMemPool (including MemPool), this relies on the C++ type system.

This should resolve #1567

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Extending S3 updater
body:
Changes:
Upgrading AWS library
Upgrading and extending the S3 updater
Fixing proxy code
Adding commons-codec dependency for AWS

All changes should be compatible with existing configurations.

The current S3 updater requires hard coded credentials. These changes allow to the S3 updater to just use the AWS [Default Credential Provider Chain](http://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdk-for-java/v1/developer-guide/credentials.html). In addition it allows the configuration of an AWS Profile to signal which credentials to use from an AWS credentials file.

The Proxy code of the current version only supported reverse proxies, now reverse proxies and authenticated http proxies are supported.

`commons-codec` is required by the AWS library for authenticated proxies.
I upgraded to the latest AWS library version, which simplified usage of `CredentialsProvider`s.

title: Adding new BytesAmount class for use by Resource
body:
Fixes #1576

The key classes to review are:
```
heron/common/src/java/com/twitter/heron/common/basics/ByteAmount.java
heron/common/tests/java/com/twitter/heron/common/basics/ByteAmountTest.java
heron/spi/src/java/com/twitter/heron/spi/packing/Resource.java
```
The rest are the downstream refactors to replace `longs` with `ByteAmounts`. Also I removed the `Constants` class since it's no longer needed, since `MB` and `GB` are no longer used.

Please review and provide feedback on the design, naming, etc of the proposed `BytesAmount` class. 

Passing a long for bytes results in a lot of unit conversion math and is subject to hard to track bugs. If instead we create a class to represent bytes and their units, heron code will be more robust and byte math can be simplified into methods on the object.

repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Change scale down to try to free containers
body:
Fixes #1560.

Updates `ResourceCompliantRRPacking` to scale down instances from the containers that are most imbalanced first. Also adds a bunch of unit tests for Scorers. The ranking algorithm prioritizes instances for removal as follows:

- Instances from containers with the most homogeneity (e.g., AAAA before AABB).
- When a tie occurs, instances from the container with the fewest instances
- When a tie occurs, instances from the container with the largest it.

Only making the change now to `ResourceCompliantRRPacking` to limit the scope of the PR. Once the approach is agreed upon, I can make similar changes to `FirstFitDecreasingPackingTest` which should also benefit from the same approach.

Best to review the 2 unit tests first to see what's happening.

title: Move taskId/componentIndex management into PackingPlanBuilder
body:
Fixes #1579.

The current repacking algos can cause collisions with `componentIndex`. This patch fixes that by moving managment of `taskId` and `compoenentIndex` into `PackingPlanBuilder` since the packing algos shouldn't need to handle these.

This has the added benefit of simplifying the `PackingPlanBuilder` API, since add/remove calls can work just with `componentNames`, instead of `InstanceIds`.

title: Add more tests for PackingPlanBuilder
body:
Added a bunch of tests and in doing so found some edge cases and bugs.

- Improved error messaging in a number of places
- change `return boolean` methods to instead return void and throw methods
- better handling of edge cases and defensive programming (adding/removing to/from container that doesn't exist, adding instances with taskId, componentIndex collisions)
- Identified bug #1579 to be fixed in a follow up patch to keep this one from ballooning.
- added a much easier way to test changes to packing (see how new tests in `PackingPlanBuilderTest` use `PackingTestHelper` and `AssertPacking`)

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Add a scoring-based approach to modifying packing plan
body:
Instances are often added and removed to containers based on a ranking of all containers. This adds methods to the PackingPlanBuilder API to make it easy to do so without requiring the caller to rank, sort and iterate through containers. Instead, packing algorithms can now add/remove instances by passing a class that scores Components based on some heuristic. Multiple scorers can be passed for primary, secondary, tertiary, etc ranking.

This patch includes an common implementation that is used for round robin placement, but other custom implementations can be passed to score based on balance, resource utilization, etc.

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Submission control flow improvment
body:
This PR addresses issue discussed in #1462. @billonahill and I decide to change the painful ""log and return null" pattern to exception handling. In addition, error message propagation from Java class to Python has been improved. User no longer needs to find error message hiding in long Java program stack trace. Instead, when invoking Java class using `subprocess.Popen`, Python side will use `communicate` to get stdout and stderr of Java class. We decide to let Java program to use `stdout` to pipe meaningful error message to the Python side. Then, Python side can print out a one-line error messaging indicating what goes wrong. 

This PR is still WIP and welcomes discussion!

cc: @billonahill

title: Change local integration tests to use test status objects instead of True/False
body:
The integration test frameworks return True/False, or sometimes "success"/"fail" to denote a successful or failed test. This changes that so tests can either return a `Success` object or raise a `TestFailure` exception.

This simplifies the code because all methods in the chain no longer need to check for True/False and log before proceeding. Instead tests proceed assuming success and handle the failure exceptions if thrown. We also don't need topology cleanup calls scattered about, since we can just catch the failure and clean up.

This changes the local integration test, but I plan to change the remote tests similarly in another PR.

title: Yarn colocate tmaster and scheduler
body:
Fixes #951 

In an attempt to keep YARN AM lightly loaded, TMaster was launched in a different container. As a result TMaster and scheduler were split in two different containers. This change resolves this issue. More resources are allocated to AM and TMaster is launched in the same container as the YARN scheduler.

title: Use pipe to properly block clients when server hasn't entered event loop.
body:
The previous way of using `usleep` cannot guarantee the clients are blocked when server hasn't entered event loop, which makes``heron/common/tests/cpp/network:http_unittest`` flaky.

This PR switches to using pipe. Server will send a byte to pipe prior to entering event loop. Clients will wait(block) until the byte is read on the other side of the pipe. This makes sure that clients are properly blocked.

Test done via script
```Bash
#!/bin/sh

for i in `seq 1 1000`;
do
    bazel test --config=darwin --no_cache_test_results heron/common/tests/cpp/network:http_unittest
    if [[ $? != 0 ]]; then
      exit 1
    fi
done
```

Thanks @congwang for suggestions.

title: Change std::list to std::deque for tuple cache
body:
An STL implemented deque usually allocates memory in pools, which reduces calls into memory allocator. This also makes deque much more cache friendly than list.

In production, we observe 2.5x performance improvement with this change. Locally, I saw ~5% improvement.


repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Change scaling int tests to constantly emit a stream of tuples throughout scaling event
body:
Previously the scaling int test spouts did the following:
- emit 10 tuples
- wait for the topology update to happen
- emit 10 tuples
- send terminal

The problem with this approach is that tuples might not be sent during the scaling changes. This patches changes those tests to do the following:
- emit a tuple every second continuously
- wait for the topology update to happen
- continue emitting a tuple every second for 10 more seconds
- send terminal
- post the tuples sent to the state server

Upon topology completion, the test runner would then fetch the dynamic set of expected results from the state server, instead of from a static expected results file.

repo.name: incubator-heron
repo.description: Apache Heron (Incubating) is a realtime, distributed, fault-tolerant stream processing engine from Twitter

title: Optimize container allocation 950
body:
Fixes #950 

The containers allocated by YARN could be bigger than the requested size. This is a consequence of a YARN scheduler optimization, which allocate resources in fixed memory and cpu increments. For e.g. if the memory increment is 100 MB, YARN may allocated a container of 200 MB when 150 MB is requested. As a result, the actual resource allocation may be little more than what was requested. Moreover YARN does not provide any mechanism to match the container request to allocated container. So the AM has no way to know which ContainerPlan to launch in the allocated container.

To avoid confusion, in the first implementation the AM would requests one container at a time. Only when the container is requested and configured, a new container request is made. This serial request-allocation cycle could be slow. In this new implementation, the serial container request mechanism is replaced with concurrent requests. The AM now provides a method to perform find a largest fitting heron ContainerPlan in the allocated container to address the issue described above.

Concurrent implementation seems to have improve topology start time by 3x to 5x. In one of the test involving 200 Containers, the new implementation took 45 seconds compared to 260 seconds earlier.

There are a few more edits I'd need to make (possibly in others PR) but wanted to share this to get feedback on the approach:
- Add checking that all required setters were called before adding/removing instances (DONE)
- `Packing.pack` and `Packing.repack` should throw `PackingException` instead of returning null. I'd do this in another PR.
- Some of the `PackingUtils` code is now only used by `PackingPlanBuilder`, so it could move there as internal utils.
- Some unit tests for just `PackingPlanBuilder`.

cc/ @avflor @ashvina @maosongfu

title: Add version in tracker and UI
body:
This PR
1. Add `version` subcommand for `heron-tracker` and `heron-ui`
2. `API_VERSION` in `heron/tools/tracker/src/python/constants.py` picks up version number from `release.yaml`.
3. Add `VERSION` constant in `heron/tools/ui/src/python/consts.py`, which also picks up version number from `release.yaml`

The key to solve the long-existing problem that `heron-ui` built with `zip_safe = False` flag is agnostic about the location of `release.yaml` is to zip `release.yaml` into `heron-ui` PEX file at compile time. See [here1](https://github.com/twitter/heron/compare/tracker-ui-version?expand=1#diff-20422e673bb9505a470407f3d2397ed2R34) and [here2](https://github.com/twitter/heron/compare/tracker-ui-version?expand=1#diff-2030bd7a10d92365e9bb96545104d00fR32).

Can verify `heron`, `heron-explorer`, `heron-tracker`, and especially `heron-ui` work fine.

cc @billonahill @kramasamy @maosongfu

title: Change integration test harness to support scaling tests
body:
Made a number of changes to support scaling tests:
- If json test configs in `updateArgs`, the test is considered a scaling (i.e., update) test
- Added `MultiPhaseTestSpout` which outputs tuples, polls for `topology_updated` state changes on the `http_server` and outputs more. This class relies on `HttpGetCondition` that polls for expected state.
- Changed the python test runner to handle update tests by:
  - poll for `topology_started` state.
  - update the topology
  - proceed with the result verification

Apologies that this PR got large, but it was a hard one for me to break up.

There is still more work to be done to handle tests the scale down. Currently the aggregator bolt waits for teminal tuples from all upstream instances so removing one leaves it hanging. Will tackle that in a separate review.

title: Use argparse + make chmod not fail in all cases
body:
This PR has two components to it:
- Refactor executor script a bit to use argparse. This shouldn't impact any runtime behavior. This just makes it so adding and removing parameters no longer requires shifting that giant array of arguments around. Shifting of parameters here caused some tricky to debug issues with our usage of Heron, and this should make figuring things out a bit easier.
- Change the way permission handling works a bit. The script originally just blindly attempted to chmod the log dirs and the various binaries. In a docker-based environment this ended up causing some issues for us. The executor had permission to execute these binaries already, so it didn't need to chmod them. However, it did not have permission to chmod them. As a result, this script would fail and abort even though it didn't actually need to change permissions. This solution seems a bit hacky, so I'm definitely open to something cleaner if anyone has any ideas.

title: Simplify how to run aurora int tests locally
body:
Adds some features to the aurora integration tests:
- ability to specify a different cli config path
- ability to only run a subset of tests
